questions.text: Which of the following is a common cause of cardiogenic shock?
questions.solution:
Option A (Myocardial infarction): Correct. Myocardial infarction is a primary cause of cardiogenic shock, where the heart's ability to pump blood is compromised due to damaged heart muscle, resulting in poor tissue perfusion.

Option B (Pulmonary embolism): Incorrect. Pulmonary embolism leads to obstructive shock, not cardiogenic shock. It causes a blockage in the pulmonary circulation, reducing blood flow to the lungs.

Option C (Hypovolemic shock): Incorrect. Hypovolemic shock is caused by a significant loss of blood volume, leading to reduced venous return and low cardiac output. This is a different type of shock, not cardiogenic.

Option D (Acute pancreatitis): Incorrect. While acute pancreatitis can lead to systemic complications and multi-organ failure, it does not directly cause cardiogenic shock. It may cause septic shock or hypovolemic shock due to fluid loss or infection.

Key Points:

  • Cardiogenic shock is due to the heart's failure to pump blood effectively, most commonly due to myocardial infarction.
  • Other causes of cardiogenic shock can include cardiac dysrhythmias, valvular heart disease, cardiomyopathy, and blunt myocardial injury.
  • Coexisting venous hypertension with pulmonary or systemic edema is common in cardiogenic shock.

Topic: Cardiogenic Shock

Reference: Bailey and Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, Chapter-2, PAGE NO. -12

choices.text: Do not extend beyond the boundaries of the original wound
Occur more commonly in individuals with lighter skin pigmentation
Often occur as a result of relatively minor trauma in individuals with darker skin pigmentation

questions.text: Which of the following is true about keloid scars?
questions.solution:
Option A (Do not extend beyond the boundaries of the original wound): Incorrect. Keloid scars extend beyond the boundaries of the original incision or wound, unlike hypertrophic scars, which do not.

Option B (Spontaneously regress over time): Incorrect. Keloid scars do not spontaneously regress and are known for being persistent and difficult to treat. This is in contrast to hypertrophic scars, which may eventually regress.

Option C (Occur more commonly in individuals with lighter skin pigmentation): Incorrect. Keloid scars are more common in individuals with darker skin pigmentation, particularly in those of African, Asian, and Hispanic descent.

Option D (Often occurs as a result of relatively minor trauma in individuals with darker skin pigmentation): Correct. Keloid scars often result from relatively minor trauma and are more prevalent in individuals with darker skin pigmentation.

Hypertrophic Scar

Keloid

Key Points:

  • Keloid scars: Extend beyond the original wound, do not regress, and are difficult to treat. They are more common in people with darker skin and occur due to minor trauma.
  • Hypertrophic scars: Stay within the boundaries of the original wound and may regress over time. They are more common in areas of tension or deep dermal burns.

Tags:

Topic: Scars and Wound Healing

Reference: Bailey and Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, Chapter-3, PAGE NO. -28

questions.text: Which of the following suture materials is most appropriate for use in gastrointestinal and muscle surgery?
questions.solution:
Option A (Catgut): Incorrect. Catgut is used for ligating superficial vessels and in tissues that heal rapidly, but it is not ideal for gastrointestinal and muscle surgeries, which require longer support.

Option B (Polyglactin/Vicryl): Correct. Polyglactin (Vicryl) is a braided multifilament suture commonly used in gastrointestinal and muscle surgeries due to its ability to support tissues while providing effective wound closure.

Option C (Polydioxanone): Incorrect. Polydioxanone is a monofilament suture, suitable for tissues requiring slightly longer wound support, but not typically used for gastrointestinal or muscle surgeries.

Option D (Polypropylene/Prolene): Incorrect. While commonly used for cardiovascular surgery and vascular anastomosis, polypropylene (Prolene) is not typically used in gastrointestinal and muscle surgeries.

Key Points:

  • Polyglactin (Vicryl): Commonly used in gastrointestinal and muscle surgeries due to its strength and absorbable nature.
  • Catgut: Used for ligating superficial vessels but not for surgeries requiring prolonged support.
  • Polydioxanone: Suitable for tissues requiring longer support but not typically for gastrointestinal or muscle surgeries.
  • Polypropylene (Prolene): Preferred for vascular and cardiovascular surgeries, not for gastrointestinal or muscle surgeries.

Tags:

Topic: Suture Materials

Reference: Bailey and Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, Chapter- 7, PAGE NO. -106

choices.text: Combines ultrasonic vibrations with feedback sensing to seal vessels up to 7 mm, minimizing tissue damage
Uses ultrasonic vibrations to denature proteins, reducing heat generation and providing precise cutting
Combines ultrasonic vibrations with bipolar diathermy, seals vessels up to 7 mm, and minimizes smoke
Uses bipolar technology to fuse vessel walls with pressure and energy, providing controlled energy delivery

questions.text: Which of the following is a correct description of the mechanism and advantage of the Thunderbeat device?
questions.solution:
Option A: Incorrect. This mechanism describes LigaSure, not Thunderbeat, which uses a combination of ultrasonic vibrations and bipolar diathermy.

Option B: Incorrect. This mechanism describes the Harmonic Scalpel, which uses ultrasonic vibrations to denature proteins, reducing heat generation and providing precise cutting.

Option C: Correct. Thunderbeat combines ultrasonic vibrations with bipolar diathermy for vessel sealing and tissue dissection, allowing faster operation, sealing vessels up to 7 mm, and minimizing smoke.

Option D: Incorrect. This describes the LigaSure device, not Thunderbeat.

  1. Bipolar Electrosurgery Devices:
    • Example: LigaSure.
    • Mechanism: Uses bipolar technology with feedback sensing to fuse vessel walls by combining pressure and energy, sealing vessels up to 7 mm in diameter.
    • Advantages: Reduces the need for instrument handling and provides controlled energy delivery with minimal tissue damage.
  2. Ultrasonic Energy Devices:
    • Example: Harmonic Scalpel.
    • Mechanism: Uses ultrasonic vibrations to denature proteins, creating a seal while simultaneously cutting tissue.(20-50000 HZ)
    • Advantages: Less heat generation, reduced smoke, and precise cutting.
  3. Combination Energy Devices:
    • Example: Thunderbeat.
    • Mechanism: Combines ultrasonic vibrations with bipolar diathermy for vessel sealing and tissue dissection.
    • Advantages: Faster operation, seals vessels up to 7 mm, and minimizes smoke.

Key Points:

  • Thunderbeat: Combines ultrasonic vibrations with bipolar diathermy for faster operation, precise sealing, and minimal smoke.
  • LigaSure: Uses bipolar technology to fuse vessel walls.
  • Harmonic Scalpel: Utilizes ultrasonic vibrations to denature proteins for precise cutting.

questions.text: Which of the following describes the percentage of surgical site infections (SSI) in clean incised wounds with and without antibiotic prophylaxis?
questions.solution:
Option A: Incorrect. The correct figures for clean wounds with and without antibiotic prophylaxis are 1-2%.

Option B: Correct. Clean incised wounds such as thyroid surgery, breast surgery, and uncomplicated hernia surgery have a 1-2% SSI rate, both with and without antibiotic prophylaxis.

Option C: Incorrect. This percentage corresponds more to clean contaminated wounds like elective cholecystectomy or elective appendectomy.

Option D: Incorrect. The higher percentages correspond to contaminated or dirty wounds, not clean wounds.

choices.text: Clostridial Myonecrosis (Gas Gangrene) - IV Penicillin and aggressive debridement
Necrotizing Fasciitis - IV Vancomycin and surgery

questions.text: A patient with a history of diabetes presents with a traumatic wound, and the wound appears swollen, with severe pain, crepitus, and a foul-smelling brown exudate. Gram staining of the exudate reveals Gram-positive, anaerobic bacilli. What is the most likely diagnosis and appropriate next step?
questions.solution:
Option A (Clostridial Myonecrosis - Gas Gangrene): Correct. The clinical features (severe local pain, crepitus, foul-smelling exudate, and Gram-positive, anaerobic bacilli) are highly suggestive of Gas Gangrene caused by Clostridium perfringens. Treatment involves IV penicillin and aggressive debridement to remove necrotic tissue, along with wound management.

Option B (Necrotizing Fasciitis - IV Vancomycin and surgery): Incorrect. While the features may overlap with gas gangrene, Necrotizing Fasciitis is caused by a broader range of organisms (including Group A Streptococcus and mixed flora) and would be managed with different antibiotics and early surgical intervention.

Option C (Cellulitis - Oral antibiotics): Incorrect. Cellulitis presents as a more superficial, non-necrotizing infection and would not cause crepitus or produce a foul-smelling exudate. It is typically treated with oral antibiotics, not IV penicillin or debridement.

Option D (Staphylococcal Abscess - Incision and drainage): Incorrect. While abscesses are a common feature of infections, the systemic signs of severe infection, crepitus, and the specific appearance of the exudate point more towards gas gangrene than a simple abscess.

Key Points:

  • Gas Gangrene is a rapidly progressing, life-threatening infection typically caused by Clostridium perfringens.
  • Prompt identification and treatment are crucial. IV penicillin and aggressive debridement are necessary to reduce mortality.
  • Patients with high-risk factors, such as diabetes, trauma, or immunocompromised, should be closely monitored for signs of this condition.

Tags:

Topic: Gas Gangrene

Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, Chapter- 5 page no. 57

questions.text: A patient presents with severe sepsis and a lactate level >4 mmol/L. Based on the Sepsis Six bundle, which of the following is NOT part of the recommended management?
questions.solution:
Option A (Give intravenous fluid challenge): Correct. A key component of the Sepsis Six is the administration of an intravenous fluid challenge, aimed at improving tissue perfusion and stabilizing blood pressure in patients with sepsis.

Option B (Administer intravenous antibiotics): Correct. Early administration of broad-spectrum intravenous antibiotics is essential in the management of sepsis to control the underlying infection.

Option C (Perform blood cultures): Correct. Blood cultures are necessary to identify the causative organism and guide antibiotic therapy, and this is part of the Sepsis Six.

Option D (Administer vasopressors immediately): Incorrect. While vasopressors may be required later in sepsis management to support blood pressure after fluid resuscitation, they are not part of the Sepsis Six within the first 6 hours unless the patient remains hypotensive despite adequate fluid resuscitation.

  • Surviving Sepsis Guidelines / Sepsis Bundle
  • Within 3 hours:
    1. Measure lactate
    2. Obtain blood culture
    3. Administer broad-spectrum antibiotics
    4. Administer IV crystalloids for hypotension or lactate ≥ 4 mmol/L
  • Within 6 hours:
    1. Vasopressors
    2. Measure central venous pressure (CVP)
    3. Measure central venous oxygen saturation (ScvO2)

Key Points:

  • The Sepsis Six bundle is designed to be completed within the first hour of identifying severe sepsis or septic shock.
  • The primary goals include resuscitation, infection control, and monitoring, with fluid resuscitation and antibiotic administration being the immediate priorities.
  • Vasopressors are used after initial fluid resuscitation if the patient remains hypotensive.

Tags:

Topic: Sepsis Management

Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, Chapter-5, Page 59.

choices.text: Serological testing for Echinococcus granulosus antibodies and CT scan for confirmation
Immediate surgical intervention for cyst removal
Needle aspiration for cyst drainage under ultrasound guidance

questions.text: A 40-year-old male from a rural sheep-farming community presents with right upper quadrant pain, jaundice, and a palpable mass. Ultrasound reveals a large cystic lesion in the liver with multiple daughter cysts. The patient reports close contact with infected dogs during his farming activities. Based on the clinical presentation and findings, which of the following is the most appropriate next step in diagnosis and management?
questions.solution:
Option A (Serological testing for Echinococcus granulosus antibodies and CT scan for confirmation): Correct. The patient's clinical presentation, including cystic lesion with daughter cysts in the liver, and history of exposure to infected dogs strongly suggest Hydatid disease caused by Echinococcus granulosus. Serological testing and imaging (CT or ultrasound) are key diagnostic tools for confirming the diagnosis, as they can demonstrate the cystic structure and help assess the involvement of daughter cysts. CT scan is often preferred for its detailed imaging, while serological tests detect antibodies against Echinococcus.

Option B (Immediate surgical intervention for cyst removal): Incorrect. Surgery may be indicated for treatment, but it is not the first step. Diagnosis should be confirmed first through imaging and serological testing. Surgery is typically performed when there are complications such as cyst rupture, infection, or obstruction.

Option C (Empirical treatment with broad-spectrum antibiotics): Incorrect. Although broad-spectrum antibiotics are commonly used for bacterial infections, hydatid disease is a parasitic infection caused by Echinococcus granulosus. Antibiotics will not treat the underlying disease, so empirical antibiotic therapy is not appropriate in this case.

Option D (Needle aspiration for cyst drainage under ultrasound guidance): Incorrect. Needle aspiration is not the recommended approach for hydatid cysts due to the risk of cyst rupture and dissemination of the larvae. Management typically involves medical treatment with albendazole or mebendazole, followed by surgery if necessary. Aspiration is contraindicated in hydatid disease due to the risk of secondary spread.

Key Points:

  • Hydatid disease, caused by Echinococcus granulosus or Echinococcus multilocularis, presents with cystic liver lesions, often with multiple daughter cysts.
  • Serological testing for Echinococcus antibodies and imaging (ultrasound or CT) are essential for diagnosis.
  • Surgery is often indicated for larger or symptomatic cysts, but diagnostic confirmation is required first.
  • Albendazole or mebendazole are the drugs of choice for medical management before considering surgery.

Tags: Topic: Hydatid Disease

Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, Chapter-6 ,page number:. 73

questions.text: A 40-year-old male living in a rural area of Sudan presents with a chronic, painless swelling on his foot. Over time, the swelling has increased in size, and there are multiple draining sinuses discharging seropurulent material. On examination, the skin is shiny, and the underlying tissue appears destroyed. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option A (Eumycetoma): Correct. Eumycetoma is a chronic granulomatous disease caused by true fungi, typically occurring in the "mycetoma belt." It presents with a triad of painless subcutaneous mass, multiple sinuses, and seropurulent discharge, as seen in this patient. The condition is common in individuals living in endemic areas like Sudan, where minor trauma, such as stepping on thorns, leads to inoculation of the fungus.

Option B (Actinomycetoma): Incorrect. Actinomycetoma is also a form of mycetoma but is caused by bacteria, rather than fungi. The clinical features may resemble eumycetoma, but the causative organisms are different. Actinomycetoma tends to be more common in certain areas but is distinguished from eumycetoma based on the causative organism and microbiological findings.

Option C (Tuberculosis): Incorrect. Tuberculosis can cause chronic ulcers or lesions, but it does not typically present with the classic features of mycetoma, such as sinuses and purulent discharge. Mycetoma also tends to affect the foot, while tuberculosis lesions are more common in the lungs or other organs.

Option D (Leprosy): Incorrect. While leprosy can cause skin changes, it typically presents with nerve involvement, loss of sensation, and characteristic deformities like leonine facies or claw hand, which are not seen in this case. Mycetoma, on the other hand, is characterized by granulomatous tissue destruction and draining sinuses.

Key Points:

  • Mycetoma is a chronic, progressive, and granulomatous disease that results from fungal or bacterial infection.
  • Eumycetoma is caused by fungi, while actinomycetoma is caused by bacteria.
  • The disease typically presents with a painless mass, sinuses, and seropurulent discharge, causing tissue destruction and deformities.

Tags:

Topic: Mycetoma

Reference: Bailey & Love’s Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, Chapter -6, Page number: 81

questions.text: A 30-year-old male immigrant from an endemic region presents with a history of general ill health, altered bowel habits, and a right iliac fossa mass. Imaging shows features of intestinal obstruction. Histological examination reveals epithelioid cell granulomas with caseation. Based on the presentation, which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option A (Crohn's Disease): Incorrect. While Crohn's disease can present similarly with right iliac fossa mass and bowel obstruction, the histological features in this case (epithelioid granulomas with caseation) are more suggestive of tuberculosis. Crohn's disease typically lacks caseation and often shows non-caseating granulomas.

Option B (Intestinal Tuberculosis - Ulcerative type): Correct. The presentation of a right iliac fossa mass with features of intestinal obstruction and the histopathology showing caseating granulomas is characteristic of intestinal tuberculosis, specifically the ulcerative type. This form of tuberculosis leads to strictures and bowel obstruction due to the necrotic and ulcerative process.

Option C (Ulcerative Colitis): Incorrect. Ulcerative colitis does not typically cause granulomatous inflammation or caseation. It presents with mucosal inflammation, often in the colon, and does not typically result in strictures like seen in tuberculosis.

Option D (Colorectal Cancer): Incorrect. While colorectal cancer can present with an obstructive mass, it does not cause the specific granulomatous inflammation and caseation seen in this case. The absence of typical clinical features and the presence of caseating granulomas make colorectal cancer less likely.

Key Points:

  • Intestinal Tuberculosis: Often presents with nonspecific symptoms, including altered bowel habits, weight loss, and right iliac fossa mass. The ulcerative type leads to strictures, while the hyperplastic type leads to mass formation.
  • Histopathology: Caseating granulomas with epithelioid cells are a hallmark of tuberculosis. Non-caseating granulomas are more typical of Crohn's disease.
  • Peritoneal Involvement: Tuberculosis can also involve the peritoneum, leading to loculated ascites or a "cocoon" appearance.

Tags:

Topic: Intestinal Tuberculosis

Reference: Bailey & Love’s Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, Chapter- 6, Page number:87.

choices.text: Resuscitation of a patient in shock

questions.text: A 50-year-old male undergoing pelvic surgery is positioned with the head end of the table tilted down and the knees slightly flexed. This positioning is also commonly used in which of the following situations?
questions.solution:
Option A (Head and neck surgery): Incorrect. For head and neck surgeries, a slight neck extension (Rose's position) is typically used, not the Trendelenburg position.

Option B (Resuscitation of a patient in shock): Correct. The Trendelenburg position, where the head end of the table is tilted down and the knees slightly flexed, is often used in shock to increase venous return and improve cardiac output during resuscitation.

Option C (Breast surgery): Incorrect. For breast surgery, the arms are extended to provide access to the axillary region, but the Trendelenburg position is not typically used.

Option D (Abdominal surgery): Incorrect. The Trendelenburg position is not specifically indicated for abdominal surgery unless there is a specific need for it, such as during laparoscopic pelvic surgery to help move abdominal organs away from the pelvic region.

Supine position:

MC surgical position, patient lies with back flat on operating room bed

Trendelenburg position:

Same as supine position but the upper torso is lowered

Reverse Trendelenburg position:

Same as supine but upper torso is raised & legs are lowered

Fracture Table Position:

For hip fracture surgery Upper torso in supine position with unaffected leg raised. Affected leg is extended with no lower support. The leg is strapped at the ankle and there is padding in the groin to keep pressure on the leg and hip.

Lithotomy position:

Used for gynecological, anal & urological procedures. Upper torso is placed in supine position, legs are raised and secured, arms are extended

Fowler's position:

Begins with the patient in supine position. Upper torso is slowly raised to a 90° position

Semi-Fowler's position:

Lower torso is in supine position & the upper torso is bent at nearly a 85° position. The patient’s head is secured by a restraint.

Prone position:

Patient lies with stomach on the bed. Abdomen can be raised off the bed.

Jackknife position:

Also called the Kraské position. Patient's abdomen lies flat on the bed. The bed is scissored so the hip is lifted & legs & head are low.

Knee-chest position:

Similar to the jackknife except the legs are bent at the knee at a 90° angle.

Lateral position:

Also called the side-lying position, it is like the jackknife except the patient is on his or her side.

Lloyd-Davies position:

Common position for surgical procedures involving the pelvis & lower abdomen.

Majority of colorectal & pelvic surgery is conducted in the Lloyd-Davies position.

Kidney position:

Patient's abdomen is placed over a lift in the operating table that bends the body to allow access to the retroperitoneal space.

A kidney rest is placed under the patient at the location of the lift.

Key Points:

  • Supine Position: The most common position for general surgical procedures.
  • Trendelenburg Position: Useful in pelvic surgery and resuscitation, where the head of the table is lowered to increase venous return.
  • Reverse Trendelenburg Position: Used when the head needs to be elevated, often in abdominal surgeries.

Tags:

Topic: Surgical Positioning

Reference: Bailey and Love’s Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, Chapter-7, Page -95.

choices.text: Start cleaning from the most contaminated area
Applying antiseptic solution without allowing it to dry
Use of razor blades for hair removal

questions.text: Which of the following is the most important principle in skin antisepsis to prevent surgical site infections (SSI)?
questions.solution:
Option A (Use of alcohol-based antiseptic solution): Correct. The use of alcohol-based antiseptic solutions is recommended for skin antisepsis as it effectively removes transient organisms and dirt, thereby preventing SSIs. Alcohol-based solutions like chlorhexidine alcohol are particularly favored.

Option B (Start cleaning from the most contaminated area): Incorrect. In clean procedures, antisepsis should start from the area where the skin incision will be made and move outward. In contaminated or dirty wounds, cleaning should start from the least contaminated area.

Option C (Applying antiseptic solution without allowing it to dry): Incorrect. It is important to allow the antiseptic solution to dry before proceeding. Dripping solution can lead to contamination, especially when it pools under the patient or contacts diathermy electrodes.

Option D (Use of razor blades for hair removal): Incorrect. Hair removal should only be done if necessary, and hair clippers are preferred over razor blades to reduce the risk of skin abrasions and infection.

Key Points:

  • Skin antisepsis: Alcohol-based solutions, such as povidone-iodine or chlorhexidine, are essential to effectively reduce bacterial contamination before surgery.
  • Draping: Ensure sterile technique and avoid contamination by positioning drapes correctly and avoiding sharp towel clips.
  • Hair removal: Use hair clippers and only remove hair when it interferes with the surgical procedure.

Tags:

Topic: Surgical Technique, Skin Antisepsis

Reference: Bailey and Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, Chapter -7, Page 97.

choices.text: Blood loss 15-30%, normal heart rate, and anuria
Blood loss 30-40%, narrow pulse pressure, and confused mental status
Blood loss 0-15%, normal blood pressure, and normal mental status
Blood loss >40%, non-recordable heart rate, and massive blood transfusion required

questions.text: Based on the parameters provided, which of the following best describes the clinical features of Class III (Moderate) shock?
questions.solution:
Option A (Blood loss 15-30%, normal heart rate, and anuria): Incorrect. This description aligns more with Class III (Moderate) shock but should have an increased heart rate and confusion in mental status rather than normal heart rate and anuria.

Option B (Blood loss 30-40%, narrow pulse pressure, and confused mental status): Correct. This fits the criteria for Class III (Moderate) shock, which includes significant blood loss (30-40%), decreased pulse pressure, and altered mental status (confusion).

Option C (Blood loss 0-15%, normal blood pressure, and normal mental status): Incorrect. This description is consistent with Class I shock, where blood loss is minimal, and mental status and blood pressure are normal.

Option D (Blood loss >40%, non-recordable heart rate, and massive blood transfusion required): Incorrect. This corresponds to Class IV (Severe) shock, which involves greater than 40% blood loss and severe hemodynamic instability, including non-recordable heart rate and massive transfusion.

Key Points:

  • Class III (Moderate) shock: Characterized by significant blood loss (30-40%), narrow pulse pressure, and altered mental status (confusion). Immediate treatment with IV fluids and possible blood transfusions is necessary.

Tags:

Topic: Shock Classification

Reference: Bailey and Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, Chapter-2, page no. -15

choices.text: Abdominal pain unrelated to bowel actions
Chronic diarrhea for less than 6 weeks with negative coeliac serology
Screening for gastric cancer in high-risk individuals

questions.text: Which of the following is an indication for colonoscopy?
questions.solution:
Option A (Abdominal pain unrelated to bowel actions): Incorrect. Colonoscopy is generally indicated for abdominal pain related to bowel movements or when other signs such as rectal bleeding are present.

Option B (Chronic diarrhea for less than 6 weeks with negative coeliac serology): Incorrect. While chronic diarrhea lasting more than 6 weeks is an indication for colonoscopy, this option does not meet the time threshold for investigation.

Option C (Surveillance of inflammatory bowel disease): Correct. Colonoscopy is a key tool in the surveillance of patients with inflammatory bowel disease (IBD) for monitoring disease activity and screening for colorectal cancer.

Option D (Screening for gastric cancer in high-risk individuals): Incorrect. This is typically managed through upper gastrointestinal endoscopy (OGD) rather than colonoscopy.

Indications for Colonoscopy

  • Rectal bleeding unexplained after proctoscopy/sigmoidoscopy
  • Abdominal pain related to bowel actions
  • Iron deficiency anaemia (combined with OGD)
  • Right iliac fossa mass if imaging suggestive of colonic origin
  • Unexplained alteration in bowel habit
  • Chronic diarrhoea (>6 weeks) after sigmoidoscopy/rectal biopsy and negative coeliac serology
  • Follow-up of CRC and polyps
  • Screening of patients with a family history of CRC
  • Assessment/removal of a lesion seen on radiological examination
  • Assessment of ulcerative colitis/Crohn’s extent and activity
  • Surveillance of inflammatory bowel disease
  • Surveillance in patients with acromegaly or following ureterosigmoidostomy

Tags:

Topic: Colonoscopy Indications

Reference: Bailey and Love’s Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, Chapter- 9, Page number:157

questions.text: Which of the following immunohistochemical markers is used for diagnosing gastrointestinal stromal tumors (GIST)?
questions.solution:
Option A (CD45): Incorrect. CD45 is a marker for lymphoid cells, particularly used in diagnosing lymphoma, not for gastrointestinal stromal tumors (GIST).

Option B (CD117): Correct. CD117, also known as c-Kit, is a hallmark marker for GISTs, identifying the gastrointestinal stromal tumor's cellular origin. It is critical for confirming GISTs in immunohistochemistry.

Option C (S100): Incorrect. S100 is typically used to identify melanocytes (melanoma), not gastrointestinal stromal tumors.

Option D (Cytokeratins, CK20): Incorrect. Cytokeratins (especially CK20) are typically used to diagnose epithelial tumors, particularly colorectal carcinoma, not GIST.

Immunohistochemical Stains Used for Tumours

  • Cell type/site of origin:
    • Epithelial (carcinoma): cytokeratins
    • Lymphoid (lymphoma): CD45, CD3 (T cells), CD20 (B cells)
    • Melanocytic (melanoma): S100, HMB45, Melan A
    • Neuroendocrine: synaptophysin, chromogranin
    • Vascular: CD31
    • Myoid: desmin, actin
  • Site of origin/cell type:
    • Prostate: prostate-specific antigen (PSA)
    • Lung: thyroid transcription factor-1 (TTF-1)
    • Thyroid: thyroglobulin
    • Colorectum: cytokeratin 20 (CK20), CDX2
    • Liver: hepatocyte-specific antigen (HSA)
    • Gastrointestinal stromal tumour (GIST): CD117, DOG-1
  • Prognosis and treatment:
    • Breast carcinoma and gastric carcinoma: HER-2
    • Neuroendocrine tumours: Ki67 proliferation index
    • Screening for mutations:
    • Colorectal carcinoma: mismatch repair proteins (MLH1, MSH2, MSH6, PMS2)

Key Points:

  • Immunohistochemical markers are used to identify tumor cell origin and to assist in diagnosing specific malignancies.
  • CD117 (c-Kit) is critical for diagnosing GISTs, which are mesenchymal tumors arising from interstitial cells of Cajal in the gastrointestinal tract.

Tags:

Topic: Immunohistochemistry in Tumor Diagnosis

Reference: Bailey and Love’s Short Practice of Surgery, 28th Edition, Chapter -11, page number. 190
